content: Succinct (“ZK”) proving feels a lot like solar power, in the sense that no matter how great the options today, if you wait two years everything will be much less expensive.
Ok security and privacy folks: where do you think our world (aka our field) will be in 50 years?

I had never really thought about how bad this is, but credit card merchant fees for online transactions are punitively high for small amounts. Stripe charges 2.9% + $.30, which means a $5 transaction pays almost 9% in fees!

So apparently the xz backdoor used an Ed448 signature to sign a RCE payload. I’m fascinated by the decision to toss away 48 bytes of payload space on a > 128-bit secure signature.

What’s really special about the current round of age verification laws being passed in the states, is that there’s really no secure technology for doing age verification on the Internet. Even insecure technologies haven’t been proposed by most states.

Pro tip: if you really care about “free speech” on the Internet, the rapid rollout of unconstitutional age-verification laws across the US is what you should be focused on. 

If instead you’re whining about social media companies being mean to you, you’re just a pretender.

A thing I worry about in the (academic) privacy field is that our work isn’t really improving privacy globally. If anything it would be more accurate to say we’re finding ways to encourage the collection and synthesis of more data, by applying a thin veneer of local “privacy.”

The problem with SNARKs is that if formulating the proof takes N times more effort than re-computing the result, you need applications where succinct verification saves you that factor of N somewhere else, or where some other factor (eg privacy/ZK) is worth all the cost.

@_gerontion Several 0days have been distributed recently via targeted network injection. It’s a thing.
@_gerontion Sending a meme to your friends isn’t running an EXE.
@_gerontion You need to get a file onto some website and convince a person to send it to their friends on a group chat. This isn’t Mossad level hard.

@_gerontion “There is a vulnerable browser on my phone” is a pretty basic threat model. The idea that Signal’s “browser” is probably weird and non-standard definitely fits my mental model of that code base.

@_gerontion If the vulnerability exists in the code that downloads remote websites and produces the preview, it would protect you. If it exists on the receiver side, turning it off would protect your direct contacts (provided Signal doesn’t display images from new connections, which I hope!)
@_gerontion It’s totally plausible if the link preview code parses weird image codecs using custom code.
